awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Target-locked single molecule spectroscopy and super-resolution microscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, and co-funding from the Molecular Biophysics and Cellular Dynamics Clusters in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, Dr. Kevin Welsher and his group at Duke University are seeking new ways to enhance understanding of chemical and biological processes by measuring the function of single molecules with high precision. Specifically, they are developing "target-locked" microscopy tools to follow the rapid motions of single proteins and other cellular matter within cells in real time. The information developed in this project will help us Understand the Rules of Life by helping us see what goes on inside biological cells both at high speed and with high resolution.  The Welsher group is also developing a set of experiments for the "home spectroscopists" aimed at using smartphones to illustrate the principles of spectroscopy and optics. These experiments illustrate the color components of various samples using simple red-green-blue values. Online videos "Teachable Tidbits" are being developed with an aim of demystifying chemistry concepts that are frequently obscured by mathematics. Finally, the research is guiding graduate students into the field of microscopy, with an emphasis on learning microscopy through relatively simple numerical simulations that the students build from scratch. 

Internal molecular motions of single proteins have traditionally been investigated by single molecule Forster Resonant Energy Transfer (smFRET), which requires that the protein be tethered to a surface so that it remains in the focal volume of a microscope.  The Welsher group is developing target-locked smFRET to probe untethered single cytosolic proteins in real-time, thereby enabling studies of the effect of cellular crowding and non-equilibrium environments on fast protein domain motions which have eluded traditional smFRET.  The work should provide a more complete picture of the molecular underpinnings of cellular cargo transport by providing simultaneous measurement of "tug-of-war" motions of individual motor proteins and the local nanometer-scale cytoskeletal structure using target-locked super-resolution (TL-SR) microscopy. The high-speed, high-precision tracking and local sub-diffraction imaging of TL-SR may enable distinction between existing models of cargo trafficking. The broader impacts of this CAREER proposal focus on making microscopy and spectroscopy accessible to students at all levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This CAREER award presents significant advancements in single-molecule tracking microscopy. This effort developed and implemented 3D-SMART (3D Single Molecule Active Real-time Tracking) as a technique that can lock on to individual fluorophores in solution. This technology enables precise observation of proteins, DNA, RNA, and multicolor dynamic processes by maintaining single molecules in the microscope's focal volume at high diffusive speeds. By capturing single-molecule distributions, 3D-SMART revealed molecular properties that bulk measurements cannot, as shown in studies of chromophore binding to RNA aptamers and real-time solution-phase observation of transcription dynamics at the single molecule level.1

Towards the goal of real-time 3D single-molecule tracking in the cytoplasm in live cells, advancements in the precision of 3D-SMART were achieved. It was discovered that by strategically illuminating just the edges of a single emitter or scatterer, localization precision can be improved beyond traditional resolution limits. This approach improves the localization precision by leveraging Fisher Information and optimizing the information content of collected photons.2 Additionally, silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were integrated as probes for intracellular tracking, achieving high precision in three dimensions, while utilizing the high scattering photon signal to sample particle position at the microsecond timescale. These advancements were applied to study nanoscale dynamics in biological systems, including the interactions of peptide-functionalized nanoparticles with cellular filopodia. Using 3D-SMARTER (3D-SMART with Enhanced Resolution), it was observed that nanoscale domains exist on the surface on these cylindrical protrusions from the cell surface, which trap particles in specific domains.3 These findings offer insights into cellular processes like adhesion, migration, and drug delivery.

In addition to improving the precision with which single objects could be localized, this work developed both hardware and algorithmic improvements to overcome limited tracking speeds and confounding background signals. Replacing piezoelectric components with galvo mirrors and deformable mirrors significantly enhanced the mechanical response time to the sub-millisecond regime. This allowed faster and more robust tracking of freely diffusing DNA molecules.4 While previous iterations of 3D-SMART provided the groundwork for tracking single molecules in vitro, dealing with the potential challenges associated with tracking dim and fast single molecules in the cellular milieu must be addressed. This work developed a novel localization algorithm to help distinguish “signal” from “background” photons in a method called Combined Online Bayesian Windowed Estimation of Background and Signal (COBWEBS). COBWEBS (and its three-dimensional extension) has demonstrated resilience to background variations to maintain real-time tracking at high-speeds and low light levels in simulated data sets.5 These efforts pave the way to tracking dim molecules in the complex cellular interior.

In summary, this project advances real-time 3D single-molecule tracking towards the ultimate goal of real-time observation of rapid dynamics in the cellular interior. By combining hardware upgrades, algorithmic refinements, and novel experimental designs, this project has made significant progress in enabling detailed, real-time analysis of molecular dynamics in solution and provides critical new tools for translation of these techniques to live-cell environments.

Broader Impacts

In addition to the intellectual impacts detailed above, efforts were made to distribute knowledge to the larger scientific and educational committee. Work was disseminated through academic conferences (such as the American Chemical Society and Biophysical Society National Meetings) and through publications. To expand to a younger audience, demonstrations on using smartphones to understand fluorescence were made to local elementary-age students during visits to Duke’s “Science Under the Stars” outreach events. During the pandemic, when these types of outreach events became rare, this project contributed towards the development of outreach kits that could be distributed to the local community for students to perform at home (more information here: https://sites.duke.edu/duke_chemkits/).

Selected Publications

 

(1) Hou, S.; Exell, J.; Welsher, K. Real-time 3D single molecule tracking. Nat. Commun. 2020, 11 (1), 3607. DOI: 10.1038/s41467-020-17444-6.

(2) Zhang, C.; Welsher, K. Information-Efficient, Off-Center Sampling Results in Improved Precision in 3D Single-Particle Tracking Microscopy. Entropy (Basel) 2021, 23 (5), 498. DOI: 10.3390/e23050498.

(3) Hou, S.; Zhang, C.; Niver, A.; Welsher, K. Mapping nanoscale forces and potentials in live cells with microsecond 3D single-particle tracking. bioRxiv 2022, 2022.2006.2027.497788. DOI: 10.1101/2022.06.27.497788.

(4) Tan, X.; Hou, S.; Niver, A.; Zhang, C.; Johnson, A.; Welsher, K. D. Active-Feedback 3D Single-Molecule Tracking Using a Fast-Responding Galvo Scanning Mirror. The Journal of Physical Chemistry A 2023, 127 (30), 6320-6328. DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpca.3c02090.

(5) Niver, A. J.; Welsher, K. D. Combined online Bayesian and windowed estimation of background and signal localization facilitates active-feedback particle tracking in complex environments. The Journal of Chemical Physics 2022, 157 (18), 184108. DOI: 10.1063/5.0118317.
